title: Facebook pushes back against Apple’s App Store fees
text: Facebook joined the growing ranks of companies publicly complaining about the 30% fee that Apple collects on payments made through its App Store. Those complaints came midway through a blog post about the social network’s new feature supporting paid online events.

title: Facebook claims Apple's in-app fees hurt businesses during the pandemic
text: CNBC's Jon Fortt joins "Closing Bell" to report that Facebook is now allowing paid online events to charge users to attend events.

title: Facebook objects to Apple fees, becoming a big new app store critic
text: Two of the biggest tech companies don't see eye to eye.

title: Facebook launches support for paid online events
text: Businesses will now be able to monetize online events on Facebook, thanks to a new feature that the social network is launching in the United States and 19 other countries today. In a call with reporters, Head of Facebook App Fidji Sumo said that Facebook’s Events feature was designed for in-person events, but with the […]

title: Facebook critiques Apple on its commission system
text: Facebook Inc said on Friday that Apple Inc has declined its request to waive off the 30% commission fee it takes from apps listed on iOS devices, making a rare critique of a fellow big tech peer.

title: Unusually Large Facebook Option Trades Suggest 2020 Rally Has Legs
text: Facebook, Inc. (NASDAQ: FB) shares are now up 38.2% in the past year despite a seemingly never-ending stream of negative headlines.

title: Facebook says Apple refused to waive 30% fee on new paid online events feature
text: Facebook on Friday took a shot at Apple, saying the company will only be able to pay small businesses a portion of sales from a new paid online events feature as a result of the iOS App Store's policies.

title: Facebook announces paid online events for small businesses
text: Facebook Inc. FB, -0.31% on Friday announced a new feature for paid online events for small businesses, creators, educators, and publishers via the social-networking giant's platform.

title: Instagram’s Addictive New Feature Is A Win For Facebook Stock
text:
Instagram’s successful launch of Reels, makes Facebook stock a worthy investment as the company continues to dominate the world of short-form video content. 
The post Instagram’s Addictive New Feature Is A Win For Facebook Stock appeared first on InvestorPlace.

title: Pro-tech advocacy group backed by Facebook and other silent investors releases its first ad
text: The campaign shows the positive impact tech has had for many consumers during the pandemic at a time when they are under intense scrutiny.

title: Facebook tests TikTok-style video format on its main app in India
text: Facebook is going all in on short-form videos. After flirting with the idea in Lasso, a TikTok-clone it tested in select markets, and adding a similar feature to Instagram recently, the company is exploring a new venue for this TikTok-esque experience: The big blue app.

title: Facebook, Twitter and Google failed to protect the 2016 election. Now they want to prove they've learned their lesson
text: For the past four years, tech giants including Facebook, Google and Twitter have invested massively in beefing up their election security efforts — creating new rules for political advertisers, hiring thousands of content moderators and building ties with law enforcement. The aim has been to avoid a repeat of the 2016 campaign, which was marred by foreign meddling and highlighted how woefully unprepared social media companies were for an attack on US democracy leveraging their platforms.

title: Facebook Slammed For Abandoning Broken Drilling Equipment Undersea Off The Oregon Coast: Report
text: Some 6,500 gallons of drilling fluid and hundreds of feet of pipe could remain under the Pacific seabed following an accident with the subcontractor building undersea internet cables for the world's largest social network.

title: Facebook’s AI for detecting hate speech is facing its biggest challenge yet
text: Advancements in AI have dramatically improved the company’s ability to identify written hate speech. But when it comes to rooting out hateful images, videos, and memes, Facebook’s AI has a long way to go.

title: Why I Sold Facebook Stock
text: Facebook has broken its social contract with its users.
